TopicTitle: Why I Really Hope KSP Goes 64bit

Articles.Content:
I find that the memory limit for parts is really tough. I don't want stations with bazillion parts but I do want a toybox with a large selection to make my vessels.

It's when I try loading a pack and find that I hit that 4gb limit and KSP crashes on launch... It just makes me want to scream as it has taken a while to get there.

So for now I have to literally cut out bits I don't think I will need from mod packs. I have 12gb on my KSP machine and it's a shame I can't fully use it.

So here is me crossing my fingers that they figure out what causes KSP to crash when run at 64bit. One day the sky will be no longer the limit.

Try the Linux version, it supports 64x.

Also, Active Texture Managment is helpful, along with manual texture compressors.
I can second that. The Active Texture Management Mod by Boulder Co really did a job. Solved all my problems with one tiny installation.

Fo real. Although texture/memory reduction mods help a heck of a lot, in the mean time.

I'm thinking that if any idea of Multiplayer starts to take off, they'll really have to look more seriously at using all 64 of our bits.

EDIT

Double ninja'd. For shame =P
KSP will be 64bit when Unity spits out stable binaries (which it can do only on Linux so far) and NeoMorph, you should know how often this is asked for, this won't help it come any sooner.

IIRC, the Unity folks are pretty close to getting it stable for Windows. The unexpected and rather substantial performance improvements resulting from the engine upgrade in KSP .23.5 are making me optimistic that things are gonna be getting better in that regard.
